eng: occurring at a point of time following a reference
examples: mi moku e kili. **ni li pini, la** sijelo li pilin pona. | I ate some fruit. **After,** I was full.

jan mute a li tawa ni, taso jan pi mute lili li awen. | Almost all people went there.
tenpo poka kama la, ona tu li awen wan lon sike tu wan. | They've been together for almost three years.
mi **taso** lon ma lete. | I'm **alone** in the cold.

eng: having happened in the past, perhaps unexpectedly
examples: nasa la mi pilin e ni: ni li kama **lon tenpo pini**. | It's strange but I feel like this has **already** happened.

mi **en** sina o weka tan ma ni. | You **and** I should run away.
telo suli la telo **li** kama **li** weka. | Ocean tides come **and** go.
**o** pali e lipu sina **o** lape. | Do your homework **and** go to bed.
mi wan **e** pan **e** ko **e** kasi. | I make a sandwich out of bread, cheese, **and** salad.
len ni li pona **lon** seli **lon** lete kin. | This outfit is suitable both for hot **and** cold weather.
mi kama la mi wile moku e ko li wile anpa e sina ale. ko mi li pini. | I have come here to chew bubblegum and kick ass, **and** I'm all out of bubblegum.

jan lawa li **wile sona** e ni: jan seme li pilin ike li pali ala? | The manager asked who was out sick.
The injured person **asked** for a glass of water. | jan pakala li **wile** e telo.
sina **toki e wile** la mi pana. | **Ask** and you shall receive.
**o** weka. | I kindly **ask** you to leave.

eng: locative preposition, similar to "on" and "in." English usage is often idiomatic.
examples: mi **lon** tomo awen pi ilo tawa. | I'm **at** the bus stop.

eng: a type of neurodivergency characterized by divergence in social situations, among many other symptoms
examples: **lawa** mi li **ante**. | I am **autistic**.

eng: to design with something as a prototype (based "on")
examples: mi **pali** e ilo ni **tan** sitelen pi jan Pensiman. | I **based** this tool **on** Benjamin's designs.

eng: to be politically aligned with the speaker (originally from 4chan)

examples:
mi wile moku. | I **am** hungry.
sina o sina. | Just **be** yourself.
mi pilin la mi **lon**. | I think, therefore I **am**.

eng: a large mammal with shaggy fur, a small tail, and flat feet
examples:
mi kama alasa e soweli. | We're going on a bear hunt.
o luka ala e soweli suli. | Don't touch the bear.
lon ma Amelika lete la soweli pimeja li moku e kasi e soweli kin. | In North America, black bears are omnivores.
soweli pimeja walo ni li moku ala e kasi palisa ona tan seme? | Why is the panda not eating its bamboo?
mi pilin monsuta mute tan soweli walo pi ma lete. | I have a fear of polar bears.

eng: Koala bear, a tree-dwelling mammal native to Australia
examples: jan Minsen li jo e luka mi sama soweli lape pi ma Oselija. | Minsin clasped my arm like a koala.

tok: mije suli pi linja sijelo mute
examples: mi mije suli pi linja sijelo mute li wile unpa pi tenpo lili e mije ante mute. | I'm a bear seeking hook-ups.

jan Santa li jo e ilo musi mute. | Santa bears many presents.
jan lili tu wan li lon insa pi jan mama. | The expecting parent is bearing triplets.
noka ona li awen e linja kipisi pi tenpo ike pakala ona. | Her legs bear the scars of her trauma.
mi o esun e ilo telo sin **tan ni**: ike la ilo mi li pana lili e telo lon tenpo ale. | I need to purchase a new kitchen tap, **because** mine leaks constantly.

eng: on account of, for the purpose of
examples: mi tawa tomo mama mi **tan** moku. | I'm visiting my parents **because of** food.

tok: wile musi, pilin pi musi ala
examples: ona li **wile musi** la ona li open e musi Manka. | They were **bored**, so they decided to play Minecraft.

eng: the time period from 1 AM to 5 AM
examples: mi ken ala lape lon **tenpo pimeja** la mi kama ilo e moku tawa tomo. | When I can't sleep during **the bosseyomp**, I order takeout.

pali li wile e mi. **taso** mi wile ala pali. | My work needs me, **but** I don't want to work.
ale li pona tawa mi. ni taso li pona ala. | I like everything but that.

**soweli** mi li musi kepeken linja. | My **cat** plays with string.
kulupu mama mi li jo e **soweli tomo** tu. | My family has two **cats**.

jan pi ma Sonko li wile lukin e **soweli alasa**. | The Chinese person wants to observe a **predator cat**.
**soweli** suli li **alasa** e kulupu pi soweli lili. | The **predator cat** hunts a group of smaller animals.

eng: a board game with two players
examples: **musi supa pi jan tu** la sona pi jan Alesanta li suli tawa sona mi. | In **chess**, Alexandra's knowledge is greater than mine.

eng: small person, person who is new (to life)
examples: **jan sin** mute li tawa li musi lon ma kasi. | Many **children** are running around and playing in the park.

eng: person who is a "fruit" (of another), progeny
examples: **jan kili** mi li kama suli li kama kin e **jan kili**. | My **child** grew up and also had a **child**.

eng: to designate one option of many as the desired option
examples: mi **toki e wile** mi a! | I've **made my choice**!
mi kama jo e seme lon **suno pana**... | What will I receive for **Christmas**...
mi **weka** tan **pali** la mi musi lon kulupu mi. | During **Christmas** break I enjoy time with my family.

tok: (tenpo) suno ni: jan Jesu li kama lon
lupa pi insa nena, insa nena
examples: len meli li lili la mi ken lukin e **lupa pi insa nena**. | The woman's clothes were so small that I could see her cleavage.

eng: cut in half, in a single powerful motion
examples: mi **tu wawa** e kiwen kasi. | I **cleaved** the piece of wood right in half.

eng: taking extra mental capacity to understand
examples: toki pi jan ni li **suli nasa** la mi ken ala sona. | This person's speech was so **complex** that I couldn't understand it.

eng: a large building, e.g. an apartment complex
examples: mi lon **tomo suli** pi jan mute. | I'm in the apartment **complex**.
mi kepeken ilo kule mute lon musi Manka la, **ilo nanpa** mi li wile moli pakala. | When I use a lot of shader mods in Minecraft, my **computer** wants to explode.

eng: disgust and aversion to a stimuli
examples: mi kama lukin e sijelo pini mi pi ilo Jutu la mi **pilin nasa ike** li **wile weka** tan lukin. | When I come upon my old Youtube account, I **cringe**.
pipi en kala li **sama ala**. | Bugs are **different** from fish.
mi o lape lon tenpo **ante**. | I should go to bed at a **different** time.
toki Sonko li **wile e pali mute**. | Chinese is a **difficult** language.

sina seme? | What are you **doing**?
kon li pona e mi. | The fresh air **did** me some good.
o pali! | **Do** your job!
ona li weka e jaki kepeken telo. mi **ni** kin. | They are washing the floor, and I **do** too.
mi sona **a** e ni. | I **do** know that.

tok: jan, jan sijelo, jan pi pona sijelo
examples: **jan ni** li pona e insa mi ni: **ona li kama e telo tan moku**. | This is my **gastrointestinologist**.

tok: jan, jan sona, jan pi {field of expertise}
eng: an expert in a field who graduated with a PhD or equivalent
examples: **jan pi sona toki** li utala mute a. | **Doctors of linguistics** very frequently debate.
jan **ale** o open e lipu ona. | **Each** person should open their books.

eng: land (as opposed to sky or sea)
examples: jan li lawa e **ma** la sewi li lawa e sewi. | Whereas mortals rule the **Earth**, the divine rules over heaven.
**ko** ni **ma** li pona tawa kasi. | This **earth** is good for agriculture.

eng: the ball produced by a parent, often a bird
examples:
sina pali seme kepeken ko jelo pi **sike waso**? | What did you make with the **egg** yolk?
seme li kama lon open: mama sike anu **sike mama**? | What came first, the chicken or the **egg**?

eng: group of people based on kinship
examples: **kulupu mama** mi li wile tawa lon telo. taso mi wile ala. | My family want to travel by boat, but I don't want to join them.

ona li tawa ma weka. | She travelled to a **far** land.
tenpo kama **weka** la ken la sijelo jan li pakala ala e pilin ona. | In the **far** future, perhaps, diseases do not cause suffering.
mi kama sona e ni: ona li jo e mani mute **a**. | He turned out to be **far** richer than I'd thought.

mi kama **tan** ma Mewika. | I came **from** America.
jan mute li moli **tan** ike sijelo. | Many people die **from** disease.

pilin mi **en** pilin sina li sama ala. | You opinions differ **from** mine.
ona li sona e ike e pona. | He knows right **from** wrong.
telo li pana e kon pi jaki **nasa**. | The milk smelt **funny**.
mi en jan olin mi li **kama jo** e soweli lili suwi a! | Me and my partner **got** a pet!
sina **jo** ala **jo** e lipu ken? | Have you **got** a ticket?
o **kama** e supa tan tomo ante. jan kama li wile e ona. | Please **get** a chair from the other room for our guest.

mi **kama** wile moku. | I'm **getting** hungry.
ona li **kama** pona tawa mi. | I'm **getting** to like him.
mi **sona** a. | Yeah, I **get** it.

mi **pana** e moku e olin tawa soweli mi. | I **gave** my cat his food and his love.
tenpo pana la mi **pana** e kiwen namako kute tawa jan olin mi. | For Christmas I **got** my partner earrings.

mi uta suwi e lawa soweli. | I **gave** the kitten a kiss on the forehead.
sina wile ala wile ken e mi? | Would you like to **give** me permission?

tok: kiwen, kiwen ni: sina ken lukin e ijo pi monsi ona
eng: a hard substance that is transparent or transluscent
examples: lupa pi tomo mi la **kiwen ni** li lon: jan li lukin lon ona la ona li ken lukin e ijo pi monsi ona. | My window has a glass pane in it.

eng: to apply a wet material that can bind two objects together once dried
examples: mi pakala e suno tomo, taso mi ken **wan** sin e anpa e sewi kepeken **ko**! | I broke my chandelier, but I can **glue** the bottom and the top together!

eng: a wet material that can bind two objects together once dried
examples: **ko** ni li ken **wan** wawa e ale! | This **glue** can fix anything!
tomo ni li **tawa** ma Sinsinasi. | This train is **going** to Cincinnati.

o **weka** ala tan mi. | I don't want you to **go**, I don't want you to leave me.
mi **tawa**. | I'm **going**.
pakala la ilo li **pali** ala! | The engine just won't **go**!
open la **sewi** li lon e sewi e ma. | In the beginning **God** created the heavens and the earth.

eng: the divine characterised in terms of personhood
examples: ma Elena pi tenpo weka la jan li toki mute e **jan sewi** ona. | Ancient Greek texts share lots of stories about their **gods**.
pona **a** la mi kama ken lape! | Oh my **god**, finally I can sleep!
a! pimeja li kama suli! mi weka. | Ah! It's gotten late! **Good night**!
o lape pona, jan lili suwi o. | **Good night**, kiddo.
mi o pali. taso mi awen wile **musi**. | I should work, but I continue to want to **have fun**.

eng: the word the name starts with
examples:
**nimi open** pi nimi jan li suli tan seme? | Why is the **headnoun** capitalised?
sina kepeken **nimi lawa** seme? | Which **headnoun** do you use?

eng: communication [interjection expressing that communication is beginning]
examples: **toki** a, ale o! | **Hello**, everyone!
mi lon! | I'm **here**!
mi kama awen lon ma ni lon sike pini poka. | We moved **here** last year.

mi **jo olin** e soweli ni la ona li pilin pona kin. | When I **hug** my plush toy, they feel nice as well.
jan olin li **luka olin** e mi li mu suwi. | My partner **hugged** me and made a cute noise.
ona li **sike e luka** ona lon mi. | They **hug** me with their arms around me.
sina seli e telo **la** ona li weka. | **If** you boil water, it evaporates.
sona nanpa li **pona** tawa mi. | I **like** maths.

eng: enjoy emotionally, feel good about something
examples: mi **pilin pona** tawa sitelen lili ni. | I quite **like** this sticker.
**tenpo mute** la telo li awen li pakala e kiwen nasin. | Water **likes** to collect in puddles and ruin the concrete.
mi ken sona olin **sama** sina. | I could even learn how to love **like** you.

**ken** la mi sitelen nasa e ni. | **Maybe** I wrote this weirdly.
— ni li tomo anu seme? — **ken** a! | — Does this count as a *tomo*? — **Maybe**!

eng: smooth surface that reflects an image
examples:
mi **lukin** e mi lon **sinpin**. | I look at myself in the **mirror**.
**ilo lukin** li pana e sitelen ante. | The **mirror** gives off an inverse image.
pipi ni pi wawa ala la selo li jelo li pimeja. ni li **sama** pipi ante wawa. | The colouring of this insect **mirrors** that of a wasp.

eng: period related to the Moon orbit
examples:
**tenpo mun** nanpa luka luka li tenpo mun monsuta. | The tenth **month** of the year is spooky season.
**mun** pi ante toki li pini. | Translation **Month** has ended.

mi wile **musi** e **kalama** ni. | I want to remix these sounds into **music**.
suno pi toki pona la mi **kalama musi!** | On Toki Pona day, I will perform **music**!

eng: polar (in relation to the Northern hemisphere)
examples: **ma** Amelika **lete** | **North** America

eng: equatorial (in relation to the Southern hemisphere)
examples: mi lon ma Antasika li tawa **ma seli**. | I travel **north** from Antarctica.
mi sona **ala** e musi ni. | I am **not** aware of this game.
ona tu li sama **ala a**. | The two of them are **not at all** alike.
— ike mi a. — ike ala! **ale li pona**. | — Oh, I'm sorry. — **Not at all**.

eng: the current time, the present time
examples:
mi ken ala toki tawa sina lon **tenpo ni**. | I cannot talk with you right **now**.
o lape lon **tenpo lon** a! | Go to bed right **now**!
o lukin: **nanpa** mute li lon sitelen ni. | Take a look: there are lots of **numbers** in this picture.
kulupu musi la sina sona ala sona e **mute** pi jan kama? | Do you know the **number** of guests who will be in attendance at the party?
o **pana e nanpa** tawa supa ale. | Please **number** the chairs.

tok: toki e mute, alasa e mute,
examples: sina wile **alasa e nanpa** mun la ni li wile e wawa mute. | It's very difficult to **number** the stars.

eng: relating to, made out of, etc
examples:
ni li jan **pi** alasa kala. | This is the guy **of** hunting fish.
o awen lon tomo kiwen. | Stay in the house **of** stone.

tok: telo, ko; li tawa seli moku
eng: animal or plant fat used for cooking
examples: **telo** ni li **tawa seli moku**. | This **oil** is for cooking food.

eng: liquid fuel made from ancient organic matter, e.g. petrol
examples: a, mi o sin e **telo** lon ilo mi. | Ugh, I should really refill the **oil** in my car.

eng: to grease a mechanism to make it perform better

examples: jan mu ni li **pona** | This singer is **okay**.

eng: neither of good or bad quality
examples: a moku ni **li pona ala li ike ala**. | Hmm, this food is **okay**.

**a sona**. | **Ah, okay.**
**pona**. | **Okay!**
**a ken**... | **Okay...**
mi **ken** e ni. | I'll **okay** that.

waso li **lon** palisa kasi. | The bird is sitting **on** the tree branch.
mi tu li kama wan lon tenpo suno pini. | We got married yesterday.
soweli mi li **tawa** ilo mi. | My cat just sat **on** the keyboard.
suno li **open**. | The lights are **on**.
ona li toki **sike** e akesi. | They rambled **on and on** about lizards.
**noka** anu soweli anu ilo la sina tawa ma Sikako **kepeken** seme? | Did you go to Chicago **on foot**, by horse, or by car?
selo mute li lon **kili** ni. | There are many layers on this **onion**.
mi weka e selo **kili** li moku e insa. | I peel the **orange** and eat it.

eng: colour similar to red or yellow
examples: suno li weka lon tenpo kama poka li kama **loje**. | The setting sun has turned an **orange** hue.

eng: colour distinct from red and yellow
examples: ma Netelan la **loje jelo** li kule suli. | The colour **orange** has cultural significance for the Netherlands.
mi o kama sin tawa pali mi pi **tenpo pini**. | I should return to my **past** efforts.
sona pi **tenpo weka** li kama sin lon lawa mi. | I have remembered something from the remote **past**.

eng: a human being, a sentient or sapient being
examples: **jan** mute li sona e nasin pona. | Lots of **people** know the right way to do things.

eng: domesticated animal, typically for companionship, and not for food or monetary gain
examples: **soweli suwi** mi li lon poka mi lon tenpo ale. | My **pet** is always at my side.
o alasa ala **luka** e soweli. | Do not attempt to **pet** the dog.

eng: a style of flatbread with toppings, usually including tomato and cheese, originating in Italy.
examples: ma Newa Jo la **pan sike** li nanpa wan a! | In Nueva York, the pizza is the best!

eng: edible starchy tuber of a potato plant
examples: jan li kama jo e **kili** tan insa **ma**. | People dig up potatoes.
mi pana e **kasi** tawa ma pona. tenpo kama la ona o pana e kili. | I have replanted the **potato** to better soil, it should grow potatoes eventually.
ona li **ken** wile e len sin. | They **probably** want new clothes.
**ken suli la**, ni li ike tawa jan lawa. | The queen **probably** won't like that.
mi **wile sona** e ijo mute. | I have a lot of **questions**.

eng: procyonid (family of animals which notably includes raccoons)
examples: **kijetesantakalu** li wile moku. | The **raccoon** wants to eat.
**soweli** li weka e moku tan poki. | The **raccoon** stole food from the container.
mi **awen sona** e ijo sama ni pi tenpo majuna. | I still **remember** similar things from the past.
mi alasa **sona sin** e ni: lipu suli mi li lon seme? | I'm trying to **remember** where I put my documents.
ma mi la waso li weka lon tenpo lete li **kama sin** lon tenpo seli. | Where I live, birds leave for the winter and **return** in the summer.
sina jo e lipu tan tomo lipu la o **pana sin** e ona tawa tomo. | If you borrow a book from the library, please **return** it.
mi wile pona e sijelo mi. mi kama **tawa** kepeken **wawa**. | I decided to get back into shape. I have gotten into **running**.
ona li jo wawa e poki mi li **weka**. | He snatched my purse and **ran**.

eng: flow in the manner of a liquid
examples: telo li tan ma nena li **tawa** ma anpa. | Rivers originate in the highlands and **run** to the lowlands.
kulupu ni li **awen** lon sike mute a! | This community has been **running** for years!
mi **kepeken** ilo Winto. | I'm **running** Windows.
jan seme li **lawa** e kulupu ni? | Who **runs** this community?
jan luka luka tu li **utala tawa**. | 12 people **ran** the marathon.
jan pi soweli tomo o kepeken **supa monsi** ni. | People with dogs should use this **seat**.

ni li jan pi **kulupu sona** mi. | This is my schoolmate.
tan jaki Kowi la **kulupu sona** ale li lon ilo li lon tomo ala. | Due to Covid, all schools are virtual and not in physical buildings.

jan lili mi li tawa **tomo sona** kepeken ilo pi sike tu. | My child goes to **school** using a bicycle.
tenpo pini la mi **kama sona lon tomo** lon poka pi jan lili ante. | In the past, I learned at **school** with other children.

eng: to clean one's body with water, usually while standing or sitting. water typically flows continuously from above (cf "bathe")
examples:
jan Pasi li **telo e selo** ona. | Patty **showered**.
mi o **kama kala**. taso ni li pini la mi kama sin. | I have to **take a shower** real quick, but after that's done I'll come back.

eng: a receptical for cleaning one's body (cf "bath")
examples: mi lon **poki telo**. | I'm in the **shower**.

eng: someone who shares at least one parent, usually two
examples: **jan sama** mi li sona e toki Epanja. | My sibling knows Spanish.

eng: someone who shares at least one parent, usually two, but is specified to be nonbinary
examples: mi olin e **tonsi sama** mi. | I love my **nonbinary sibling**.

eng: someone who shares at least one parent, usually two, but is specified to be female
examples: jan Pita en **meli sama** ona li kama li jo e len mani. | Peter and his **sister** arrived clad in expensive attire.

eng: to be in a state of rest with the buttocks against a horisontal surface
examples: mi **monsi** e supa. | I'm **sitting** on a table.
mi wile e **ijo** ni: ona li pona tawa soweli mi. | I want **something** that'll please my pet.

eng: at multiple periods or instances with low to moderate frequency
examples: **tenpo** la mi moku e kala. taso ona li pona pi suli ala tawa mi. | **Sometimes** I eat fish, but it's not amazing.
ale o kama pona lon **tenpo kama poka**. | May everything get better **soon**.
**tenpo lili kama** la, jan olin sina li lon poka sina! | **Soon** your partner will be with you!
**mun** li suno wawa lon tenpo ni. | **The stars** are bright tonight.

eng: convex pointy shape, usually with five points

examples: ilo li pana e suno loje la o **kama tawa ala**. | If the traffic light is red, **stop**.
telo sewi li **pini**. | The rain **stopped**.
**tomo** ni **awen** li wile e supa sewi. | This bus **stop** needs a roof.
mi o pana e **toki**. | Let me tell you a **story**.

pali ni li wile e **tenpo** suli. | This job takes a long **time** to do.
**tenpo** seme la sina ken kama? | At what **time** can you come?
**suno ni** la mi lukin e akesi suli a. | **Today** I spotted a large lizard!
**tenpo lon** la jan lili ale li lukin e ilo ona. | Kids **today** are always on their phones.
ike la mi ken ala toki uta. taso **suno kama** la ken. | Unfortunately I cannot join the voice chat, but maybe **tomorrow**.
lipu ni li **ante e toki** pi nimi mute. | This page **translates** many phrases.
mi **toki Epelanto** e lipu ni. | I've **translated** that document **into Esperanto**.
jan **tu** li lon tomo ni. | **Two** people are in that building.
kala ni li suli **mute**. | The whale is a **very** large animal.
mi esun **a** e tomo! | I bought my **very** own house!

**lipu** Wesi | (the **website** called) Reddit
**lipu** Wikipesija | (the **website** called) Wikipedia

eng: online page with high interactivity, web app
examples:
**ilo** Siko | (the **website** called) Discord
**ilo** Kuko | (the **website** called) Google
**tenpo seme** la soweli lili li kama lon? | **When** were the kittens born?
sina tawa lon nasin **la** o awen lukin pona e ale. | Be careful **when** crossing the street.
nena li **lon seme**? | **Where** is the button?
tomo telo ni li **tawa ma seme**? | **Where** is this ship headed off to?
sewi li laso **tan seme**? | **Why** is the sky blue?
mi sona ala e **tan**. | I don't know **why**.

eng: to come first place in a competition or battle
examples: utala lili la sina anpa e mi. taso utala suli la mi **kama nanpa wan**! | You may have won the battle, but I will **win** the war!
o moku **kepeken** ilo. | Please eat **with** a fork.
mi musi **lon poka** pi jan lili. | I'm playing **with** a kid.
mi **en** jan Kesi li poka pona. | I am friends **with** Katie.
jan pali pi **ma ale** o wan! | Workers of the **world**, unite!
**ale** pi sona mi li kama pini. | It's the end of the **world** as we know it.
mi **toki** tawa ona lon tenpo mute. | I've **written** to him often.
mi **sitelen** e nimi mi. | I **am writing** my name.

eng: period related to the Earth orbit
examples: **tenpo sike** ale la ona li kama lon kulupu mama ona. | Every **year** she visits her family.
tan seme la mi nasa mute e lawa mi lon **suno pini**? | Why did I drink so much **yesterday**?
